thread.title: I don't want to campaign where Congress is contesting: Shivpal Yadav | Uttar Pradesh Elections 2017 - Times of India
thread.title_full: I don't want to campaign where Congress is contesting: Shivpal Yadav | Uttar Pradesh Elections 2017 - Times of India

author: timesofindia.indiatimes.com
title: I don't want to campaign where Congress is contesting: Shivpal Yadav | Uttar Pradesh Elections 2017 - Times of India

organizations.name: uttar pradesh elections 2017 - times of india new delhi

text:
NEW DELHI: The SP's Akhilesh Yadav and Congress leader Rahul Gandhi have been campaigning for each other in Uttar Pradesh but the state chief minister's estranged uncle Shivpal said categorically that he does not want to campaign for his party's electoral ally, ANI reported. 

He also affirmed that until March 11 (when the elections results are announced) it must be assumed he's fighting on the SP's ticket. 

"After that, if there are no insults, then I'm with it," Shivpal said cryptically about his continued association with the SP. 

On January 31, Shivpal had said that because of being "attacked repeatedly" by members of the Akhilesh faction of the SP, he will form a new party, but only on March 11, after the results of the Assembly polls are declared. 

Relations are clearly still strained between the Akhilesh camp and the camp led by his father Mulayam who has on his side his brother Shivpal. This internal feud came out in the open last September. After Akhilesh won the right to use the party's electoral symbol, a shaky rapprochement was perceived to have taken place. 

But party founder Mulayam lost his cool again when Akhilesh in late January announced an electoral alliance with the Congress. A furious Mulayam - who was against such a partnership - said that he wouldn't campaign for the Congress. 

Clearly, Shivpal also isn't in favour of the alliance. 

"I don't want to go where Congress candidates are contesting. If Netaji (party founder Mulayam Singh Yadav) wants I'll go. I will campaign for SP, I haven't thought further," said Shivpal to ANI. 

Three of seven phases of the UP elections have already taken place.
